## Chapter Three Hundred and Seventy-Nine

Concerning the knowledge of the Station of Loosing and Binding, of Honoring and Humiliating, and the origination of Supplication in the form of Narration. It is a Muhammadan Station.

> Platters made of silver *** And of essence and spring [‘ayn].
>
> Noble ones brought them to us *** Over them were veils of protection.
>
> When they appeared to us *** We ate of every color.
>
> From them are sciences and description *** And from them are sciences of the cosmos.
>
> From them are sciences of spiritual state (ḥāl) *** And from them are sciences of direct vision (‘ayn).
>
> So some speak of union (waṣl) *** And some speak of separation (bayn).
>
> Glory be to Him who is exalted *** By the similitude of every essence/eye.
>
> For His being is not other than Him *** And His being is not by my being.

### [The Twelve: The Limit of the Simple Numbers]

Know that the number twelve (12) is the limit of the simple numbers (البسائط) composed of digits (أصابع) and joints (عقد). The digits are nine of them, and the joints are three, making the total twelve. Each of these twelve possesses a ruling (ḥukm) that the others do not, and a Divine witnessing (mashhad) that belongs to no other. Corresponding to each of these numbers is a man among the servants of Allah who holds the ruling of that number.

The One (الواحد) is not counted among the numbers. This is why the Witr (وتر) prayer of the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) was eleven *rak‘ahs*. If the One were counted among the numbers, the singularity (Witr-ness) would not be valid at all, neither in the number nor in the counted objects. Thus, the Witr prayer of the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) was eleven *rak‘ahs*, and each *rak‘ah* is the origination (نشأة) of a man from his community whose heart is upon the form of the Prophet’s heart (PBUH) in that *rak‘ah*.

As for the Twelfth, he is the one who comprehends the eleven. The man who holds the station of the twelve is the Truth (Ḥaqq) entirely, outwardly and inwardly. He knows and is not known. He is the First One (الواحد الأول). For the beginning of counting is from two. When you reach twelve, you have only reached eleven of the numbers, for the First One is not counted among them. The existence of the twelve is not valid except through the First One, despite Him not being counted among the numbers. Because He holds this ruling, He is in the twelve, yet He is not it, just as one says, "You are not you."

These twelve are the ones who extract the treasures of Gnosis (كنوز المعارف) that are stored within the forms of the world (صور العالم). The world has the knowledge of the forms of the world, but these men have the knowledge of what these forms contain—the treasure within them—which they extract by means of the First One. Thus, they are the most knowledgeable of people concerning Unity (التوحيد) and Worship (العبادة). They possess the perpetual, essential intimate conversation (المناجاة) with Allah, which is maintained by the maintenance of the One for the numbers, like His saying: <<وَهُوَ مَعَكُمْ أَيْنَ مَا كُنْتُمْ>> (And He is with you wherever you are). That is, you have no specific existence apart from the One. By the One, the essences (أعيان) of the numbers appear; He is their Manifestor and their Enricher.

The letter *alif* is His description, for by the *alif* the affinity (ألفة) of the One with the degrees of number occurs due to His manifestation, for <<هُوَ الْأَوَّلُ وَالْآخِرُ>> (He is the First and the Last). If you multiply the One by itself, nothing appears externally after the multiplication except Himself. And whatever you multiply the One by, that thing neither doubles nor increases. For the One that you multiplied into that multiplicity (كثرة) was only multiplied into its own oneness (aḥadiyya), which is why no increase appeared in it. The One does not accept increase in itself or in what it is multiplied by; it does not double. It is One wherever it is. So you say, "One times one hundred thousand is one hundred thousand," and "One times two is two," and "One times ten is ten." Nothing is added to the multiplied number at all, because the station of the One is too exalted to reside in anything or for anything to reside in it. This applies whether the number is whole or fractional; there is no difference.

The One, meaning the Real (الحق), leaves the realities (الحقائق) as they are; they do not change from their essence. For if they changed, the One would change in Himself, and the Real would change in Himself, and the change of realities is impossible. No knowledge would be established at all, neither Divine nor created. Thus, it is established that realities never fundamentally change. This is why reliance is placed upon what is relied upon, which is called Knowledge (العلم).

Let us mention each man among these eleven who originated from the Witr of the Messenger of Allah (PBUH). Indeed, these forms perhaps made the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) perform the Witr of eleven *rak‘ahs* in the outward form, while these forms originated from him (PBUH) inwardly. For he was a Prophet while Adam was between water and clay, and he originated them because this was his description. When he (PBUH) appeared with his body, he maintained those spiritual forms (الصور المعنوية), and they established his body at night due to the suitability of the Unseen (al-Ghayb). They ruled over his outward form with the eleven *rak‘ahs* with which he performed the Witr. Thus, they were his Witr; they are the Rulers and the Ruled for him. From him (PBUH) they originated, and in him (PBUH) they appeared, and upon him they ruled in two different ways.

From the form of the First *Rak‘ah* originated a man from the men of Allah called ‘Abd al-Kabīr (Servant of the Great) in terms of attribute, though it is a name for him. He is a rational spiritual origination (نشأة روحانية معقولة) that, if embodied, would be in the form of a human whose description is what he is called by. And so is every form of these twelve.

### [The Superiority in the Divine Names]

Know that the superiority (المفاضلة) in the Divine Names is a higher and more majestic example, as in the saying of the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) when the polytheists chanted in their war-song, "A‘la Hubal! A‘la Hubal!" (Hubal is higher! Hubal is higher!). The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said, "Say!" They asked, "O Messenger of Allah, what should we say?" He said, "Say: Allah is Higher (A‘lā) and More Majestic (Ajall)."

They concede this much, for they are the ones who say: <<مَا نَعْبُدُهُمْ إِلَّا لِيُقَرِّبُونَا إِلَى اللَّهِ زُلْفَى>> (We only worship them that they may bring us nearer to Allah). So, He is Higher and More Majestic in their view. If they had believed the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) that he was a messenger from the Allah to whom they sought proximity by worshipping these deities, they would not have called them deities (ālihat) except because they made them objects of worship, for *ilāh* (deity) is the object of worship, and *ālihat* (deities) means worship. It has been recited: *wa yadharaka wa ālihataka* (and leave you and your deities), meaning, "and your worship." If one says *wa ālihataka*, it means "and the worshipped ones whom we worship."

Since they attributed divinity (al-ulūhiyya) to those whom they worshipped, and the attribution of divinity to Allah is more complete and greater in their own admission, the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) spoke using the structure of comparison (المفاضلة) in that context, saying to them, "This is your own saying and belief." This is why the phrase *Allahu Akbar* (Allah is Greater) came in the *takbīr* of the prayer with the structure of comparison, not because stones or what they carved or what they attributed divinity to (like a star or other things) are superior. Rather, the comparison occurred in the context of appropriateness (المناسبة), not in the essences (الأعيان), because there is no comparison between the servant and the Master, nor the Lord and the object of Lordship (المربوب), nor the Creator and the created.

If you realize what we have alluded to regarding the origination of this form, you will know what the polytheist returns to after accountability.

The origination of the form of the Second *Rak‘ah* of the Witr originated a man from the men of Allah the Exalted, called ‘Abd al-Mujīb (Servant of the Responder).

### [Response is a Branch of the Request]

Know that the response (الإجابة) is a branch of the request (السؤال). This servant is effective through his request and supplication (دعاء) upon his Master, and the Master is effective upon him by responding to His servant.

For Allah, the Mighty and Majestic, has established for Himself, upon the tongue of His Messenger (PBUH), that the servant pleases Allah, so He is pleased; the servant angers Allah, so He is angry; the servant displeases Allah, so He is displeased; and the servant makes Allah laugh, so He laughs.

And similar things that have been reported in the Book and the Sunnah. The Real (الحق) influences the servant to ask so that He may respond, and influences the displeasing act so that He may be displeased. This is so you may know that the matter is circular and spherical (دوري كروي), and that the end of the circle returns to its starting point, so the Last bends back upon the First, to be the First and the Last. Thus, none pleases Him but He, and none displeases Him but He, because He is too exalted to be influenced by other than Himself. Understand this.

Allah has no ruling (ḥukm) in the world except what we have mentioned. Do you not see Him saying: <<سَنَفْرُغُ لَكُمْ أَيُّهَ الثَّقَلَانِ>> (We shall attend to you, O you two weighty ones [men and jinn])? He has no occupation except with us. It is from us that He attends to us. If we were to cease, He would be, but there would be no existence (وجود) or estimation (تقدير). The matter cannot be rationally understood except in this way, otherwise the relations (الإضافات) would be nullified, and they are not nullified because they are relations unto themselves. Therefore, the Lord cannot be conceived without being related. That is why He never came in the Quran absolutely without relation, even if His relations differ: sometimes He is related to pronouns, sometimes to essences (الأعيان), and sometimes to states (الأحوال).

If you do not rationally understand your knowledge of your Lord in this way, then you have not known your Lord at all. You have only known by rational division that the ruling of the Necessarily Existent by His Essence (الواجب الوجود لذاته) must be such-and-such. But whether there is a Necessarily Existent by His Essence or not, you do not know Him except through yourself. And what we do not know except through you, the knowledge of it must be contingent upon your knowledge of yourself. Thus, your existence is contingent upon His existence, and the knowledge of His Lordship over you is contingent upon the knowledge of yourself. He is the origin (الأصل) in existence, and you have the ruling of the branch (الفرع) in existence; but you are the origin in the knowledge of Him, and He has the ruling of the branch in knowledge.

The origination of the form of the Third *Rak‘ah* of the Witr originated a man from the men of Allah called ‘Abd al-Ḥamīd (Servant of the Praiseworthy).

### [Praise of Allah is of Two Types: Absolute and Restricted]

Know that the praise (الثناء) of Allah is of two types: absolute (مطلق) and restricted (مقيد). The absolute is only possible with the acknowledgment of incapacity (العجز), such as His saying (PBUH):

> I cannot enumerate Your praise; You are as You have praised Yourself.

> One of them said: If we praise You with goodness *** You are the one whom we praise, and above the one whom we praise.

It is impossible for a created being to encompass the praise due to Allah the Exalted, because it is impossible for all possibilities (الممكنات) to enter into existence. Every possibility has a specific face (وجه خاص) toward Allah, from which Allah brings it into existence, from which that possibility knows Him, and from which it praises Him with a praise that only the possessor of that face knows. No one else can know it or indicate it with a word or a sign. This is the absolute praise of Allah by every tongue, past and future.

This is why the reward for the saying of the one who says, "Glory be to Allah, the number of His creation" (سبحان الله عدد خلقه), cannot be conceived as occurring in existence, but its reward continues to be found, state after state, perpetually, without end. This is also why the Law (al-Shar‘) brought it in triplicate, that the servant should say it three times, so that the sensible reward (المحسوس), the imagined reward (المتخيل), and the spiritual reward (المعنوي) may be attained. Thus, he is blessed sensually, imaginatively, and intellectually, just as he remembers sensually, imaginatively, and intellectually, and just as he worships sensually, imaginatively, and intellectually.

Similarly, the servant’s remembrance of the ink of the Divine Words (مداد الكلمات الإلهية), and the weight of His Throne (زنة عرشه)—if the Throne is the entire delimited cosmos (العالم كله بمحدده)—and similarly, the pleasure of His Self (رضا نفسه) in what the people of Paradise and the people of the Fire do. For they do not act or dispose themselves except in Divine Pleasures (المراضي الإلهية), because that abode grants them this, unlike the abode of this world and obligation (التكليف), where they dispose themselves in what pleases Allah and what displeases Him. This is because Allah made the Fire the abode of those with whom He is displeased, so its inhabitants must move in what displeases Allah in the abode of this world. But when they dwell in the abode of the Fire and inhabit it, they cannot move except in the pleasure of Allah. This is why the outcome for its inhabitants will be the ruling of the Mercy that <<وَسِعَتْ كُلَّ شَيْءٍ>> (encompassed everything), even though it is the abode of wretchedness (دار شقاء). Just as we say of the Messenger whose mission has ended and who has returned to Allah that he is the Messenger of Allah, even though he is not a messenger in that state, similarly, we say of the abode of wretchedness that it is the abode of wretchedness, even though wretchedness has departed from its inhabitants while they are in it.

As for restricted praise (الثناء المقيد), the philosophers (الحكماء) restrict it only to the attribute of Transcendence (التنزيه). Even if they praise Him with the attribute of Act (صفة الفعل), it is by the ruling of the whole or the origin (الأصالة), not by ruling for an individual.

Those other than the philosophers restrict the praise of Allah to the attribute of Act and the attribute of Transcendence together. These are the Perfect Ones (الكمل), because they shared with the philosophers what they knew and added what the philosophers were ignorant of and did not know, due to the limitation of their aspiration (همهم) caused by the ambiguity that arose for them, which ruled upon them that only the One referred to proceeded from the Exalted, and that what He described Himself with in His Book is not permissible for Him, since they did not establish in their view a revealed Book or a sent person in the manner that the matter is in itself and with the People of Unveiling (الكشف) and Faith (الإيمان). This view has been adopted by some rational thinkers, such as the theologians (المتكلمين) and others who hold this view based on rational speculation.

The ruling of the forms of these Prophetic Witr *rak‘ahs* has spread throughout the entire world from the time he (PBUH) was a Prophet while Adam was between water and clay until the Day of Resurrection.

The origination of the form of the Fourth *Rak‘ah* of the Witr originated a man from the men of Allah called ‘Abd al-Raḥmān (Servant of the All-Merciful).

### [The Divine Mercy that Allah Created in His Servants is Created from the Essential Mercy]

Know that the Divine Mercy (الرحمة الإلهية) that Allah created in His servants so that they might show mercy to one another is created from the Essential Mercy (الرحمة الذاتية) by which Allah brought the world into existence when He loved to be known, and by which He <<كَتَبَ عَلَى نَفْسِهِ الرَّحْمَةَ>> (prescribed Mercy for Himself). This Written Mercy (الرحمة المكتوبة) is passive (منفعلة) relative to the Essential Mercy.

The Gratuitous Mercy (الرحمة الامتنانية) is the one that <<وَسِعَتْ كُلَّ شَيْءٍ>> (encompassed everything). The mercy of a thing upon itself is sustained by the Essential Mercy and looks toward it. In this mercy, the witnessing (الشهود) of every compassionate one upon himself occurs. For Allah described Himself with love and intense longing (شدة الشوق) to meet His beloved ones. He only met them by the ruling of this mercy that the possessor of this mercy witnesses—the Mercy He prescribed for Himself. It has no witnessing in the Essential Mercy or the Gratuitous Mercy.

As for the mercy of the compassionate one toward the one who wronged him, and what the comprehensiveness of Divine beneficence and the vastness of Bounty (الجود) necessitate, it has no witnessing except in the Gratuitous Mercy. This is the mercy that Iblis and those below him hope for. These have no witnessing in the Written Mercy or the Essential Mercy.

By this, Allah and the All-Merciful (al-Raḥmān) were distinguished from other Names, for <<لِلَّهِ الْأَسْمَاءُ الْحُسْنَى>> (To Allah belong the Most Beautiful Names). All the Names are indications of the Name al-Raḥmān and the Name Allah, but most people do not perceive this. I have not seen anyone among the People of Allah (Ahl Allah) draw attention to the tripartition of Mercy with this division, for it is a strange division, just as it is in reality. We only learned it through Unveiling (الكشف). I do not know why our companions neglected to express it, though I suspect Allah revealed it to them. As for the Prophets, we know that they stood upon this knowledge with direct vision (‘ayn), and we knew it from the light of their niche, because Allah granted us Divine Following (الاتباع الإلهي) and Prophetic Following (الاتباع النبوي).

As for Divine Following, it is His saying, <<وَهُوَ مَعَكُمْ أَيْنَ مَا كُنْتُمْ>> (And He is with you wherever you are). In this company (ma‘iyya), Allah follows the servant wherever he is. We, too, follow the Exalted wherever He manifests by a ruling. We remain still until He manifests by a command that gives a specific ruling in existence, and then we follow Him in it. We do not appear in public contrary to it, such as our silence regarding defining Him as "He" when He manifests in a form that is denied, even though we know Him. He is the one who precedes with the Theophany (التجلي) and the ruling of denial, so we follow Him by silence, neither denying nor affirming. This is Divine Following.

As for the Prophetic Following that Allah granted us, it is His saying, <<لَقَدْ كَانَ لَكُمْ فِي رَسُولِ اللَّهِ أُسْوَةٌ حَسَنَةٌ>> (Indeed, in the Messenger of Allah you have a good example). Furthermore, He followed us and took us as an example in his prayer when he prayed with the congregation, where there might be the weak, the sick, and the one with a need, so he prayed according to their prayer. Thus, he (PBUH) was the follower (متبع) and the followed (متبوع)—both active and passive participles. Then He commanded us, when we are imams, to pray according to the prayer of the weakest among us.

We follow the All-Merciful (al-Raḥmān) in what we mentioned, so we are the followers. And we follow the All-Merciful in what our realities necessitate of need and destitution, so He proceeds according to our state, and thus we are the followed. Look at what the realities of Lordship (al-siyāda) grant to the servants, and what the realities of worship and servitude (al-‘ubūdiyya) grant to Lordship.

This man possesses this description in the world. By this Fourth *Rak‘ah*, the rulings of the four Divine Names appeared, as well as the rulings of Nature (الطبيعة) in the natural origination (النشأة الطبيعية), the rulings of the elements in the three generated realms (المولدات الثلاثة) that possess these three Mercies, and the rulings of the humors (الأخلاط) in the animal origination (النشأة الحيوانية). Therefore, this man has dominion (المهيمنية) over all of these.

The origination of the form of the Fifth *Rak‘ah* of the Witr originated a man from the men of Allah called ‘Abd al-Mu‘ṭī (Servant of the Giver).

Sometimes his giving is a gift (wahb), so the Giver is ‘Abd al-Wahhāb (Servant of the Bestower). Sometimes his giving is a favor (in‘ām), so he is ‘Abd al-Mun‘im (Servant of the Favorer). Sometimes his giving is generosity (karam), so the Giver is ‘Abd al-Karīm (Servant of the Generous). Sometimes his giving is bounty (jūd), so the Giver is ‘Abd al-Jawwād (Servant of the Bountiful). Sometimes his giving is liberality (sakhā’), so the Giver is ‘Abd al-Muqīt and ‘Abd al-Sakhī (Servant of the Sustainer and Servant of the Liberal). And sometimes his giving is altruism (īthār), so the Giver is ‘Abd al-Ghanī (Servant of the Rich/Self-Sufficient).

This giving is the most obscure of all givings and the most difficult to conceive; indeed, everyone denies it except us. We have not seen anyone establish this giving in Divine matters (الإلهيات). None establishes it except one who knows the meaning of His Name, al-Ghanī (The Self-Sufficient), the Exalted. This is because it is established in the *Ṣaḥīḥ* collection that the servant reaches a station where the Real (الحق), in terms of His Identity (Huwiyya), becomes all his powers, as in His saying:

> I was his hearing, his sight, and his hand.

And the rest of his limbs and powers, as mentioned in the Hadith. He, Glory be to Him, is Self-Sufficient by His Essence (الغني لذاته), a Self-Sufficiency that cannot be removed from Him. When the servant stands in this station, He has given him the attribute of Self-Sufficiency from Him and from everything, because His Identity is the very essences (أعيان) of this servant’s powers. This is not found in the divisions of giving except as altruism (الإيثار). He has preferred His servant with what belongs to His Identity. He the Exalted said: <<وَيُؤْثِرُونَ عَلَى أَنْفُسِهِمْ وَلَوْ كَانَ بِهِمْ خَصَاصَةٌ>> (And they prefer [others] over themselves, even though they are in need). Indeed, they are in need.

Since the giving of altruism is a favor (faḍl) that returns to the Giver, the Real is more deserving of the attribute of Favor. Thus, the giving of altruism is more appropriate for the Real and more complete for the servant. This is one of the sciences of secrets (علوم الأسرار) whose definition cannot be fully elaborated except by allusion to its people, encouraging them to act upon it, for they are in extreme fear of accepting it, let alone being characterized by it. The rest of the Names are of lesser concern.

The origination of the form of the Sixth *Rak‘ah* of the Witr originated a man from the men of Allah called ‘Abd al-Mu’min (Servant of the Giver of Security/The Believer).

### [That Faith is a Divine Attribute]

Know that Faith (الإيمان), when it is a Divine attribute (نعت إلهي), is what appears from all the indications (الدلالات) that confirm the validity of the claim made by any claimant, whatever the claim, without specific designation, provided that it is a proof (dalīl) in itself. This is witnessed by the senses if the proof is sensible, such that if it grants necessary knowledge (العلم الضروري) of the truth of this claim in the mind of the judge, that necessary knowledge is the very proof of the truth of the claimant’s assertion.

The Establisher of these indications is the Affirmer (المصدق) of the claimant. When the one who affirms him does so, and the knowledge of this is attained in the soul of the one who attained it, that person who possesses this proof becomes an affirmer of the claimant. Thus, the affirmation returns to being cosmic (كونيا)—that is, in creation (al-Khalq)—just as it is in the Real (al-Ḥaqq). The claimant is thus confined between two affirmers; wherever he turns, he finds only an affirmer of what he brought in his claim. This state grants him security (الأمان) within himself from being denied by these two sides. Even if the cosmos denies him, he is certain within himself of the claimant’s truthfulness. This is the only goal: the attainment of knowledge of his truthfulness.

By the form of this *rak‘ah*, affirmation spread in the world of humans and jinn in their inner beings. This occurred when this *rak‘ah* took place in the inner reality, when he (PBUH) was a Prophet while Adam was between water and clay. It continued to spread as a pure spirit (روحا مجردا) in every affirmer until he (PBUH) performed it in the form of his body, and it became embodied. That spirit is not a bodily form resulting from his act, because it arises from sensible movements. Its act was stronger in our view because it combined the two forms, just as his influence (PBUH) through the appearance of his body was stronger in his mission than when he was a Prophet while Adam was between water and clay. For by the form of his mission, he abrogated all previous laws (الشرائع), and no law remained valid except what he maintained from it, in the sense that it was a law for him, not merely a law in itself.

The origination of the form of the Seventh *Rak‘ah* of the Witr originated a man from the men of Allah called ‘Abd al-Raḥīm (Servant of the Merciful).

Know that Mercy (الرحمة) in the essence of the one capable of manifesting its ruling turns into painful torment (عذاب أليم) for the one in whom it resides, because its essence demands reaching out to the object of mercy (المرحوم) and manifesting its effect through action upon him. If it resides in the one capable of executing it upon the object of mercy, it has an effect that influences the compassionate one (al-Rāḥim), which is the removal of the pain he felt by the effect occurring in the object of mercy. The compassionate one is shown mercy by it, in terms of his ability to execute it. The one upon whom it is executed is also shown mercy by it and by the compassionate one’s ability to execute it. Thus, its effect upon him is from two aspects. The effect is the removal of what caused the compassionate one pain due to the attachment of mercy to that object of mercy.

Not all mercy is bliss (na‘īm) unless the compassionate one is capable of executing it. Mercy has a Theophany (تجلي) in the form of torment in the case of the compassionate one who lacks the power to execute it, and it has a Theophany in the form of bliss in the case of the compassionate one and the object of mercy if it resides in one capable of executing it. Thus, it has inverted the two opposing forms. This is one of the most astonishing matters: that mercy produces pain and torment. If mercy did not reside in him, this powerless one would not be characterized by pain.

The most astonishing aspect of this issue is that the mercy residing in the one characterized by the execution of power may have a barrier from his own essence preventing its execution. This causes him the pain of aversion (ألم الكراهة), which is the ruling of that barrier, despite his being characterized by the power to execute it. This issue is one of the most difficult in Divine Knowledge (العلم الإلهي).

The ruling of this appeared in the authentic Divine reports about Himself, the Mighty and Majestic, where He said:

> I have not hesitated about anything I am going to do as much as I hesitate about taking the soul of My believing servant, who dislikes death, and I dislike causing him distress, but he must meet Me.

It is He who made him dislike death, and He indicated that meeting Him only occurs through death, which is the departure from the absolute sense (al-Ḥiss al-Muṭlaq) to the shared sense (al-Ḥiss al-Mushtarak), as you see in sleep, for sleep is a type of death. It is a demise (wafāt) and a transition from the world of sense to the world of Imagination (al-Khayāl) and the shared sense. The sleeper sees his Lord in his sleep, just as the dead person sees his Lord after his death. However, the vision and meeting of the dead person is without return after his vision, while the sleeper awakens, sent forth until the appointed term. If the meeting is due to annihilation (fanā’) and not sleep, and then he is returned to the state of subsistence (baqā’), his ruling is like that of the dead person when he is resurrected on the Day of Resurrection: no veil falls upon him thereafter. This is the difference between the sleeper and the annihilated one (al-Fānī).

That is why ‘Amr ibn ‘Uthmān al-Makkī said concerning the description of the Gnostics (‘Ārifīn): "They are today as they will be tomorrow, if Allah wills." He saw nothing more astonishing than the ruling of Mercy. Do you not see the physician who feels mercy for the patient with a gangrenous wound, yet cannot execute that mercy upon him except by causing him pain? The measure of that physician’s mercy for the patient is the measure of his own pain, due to his inability to execute the mercy without causing pain. If he did not have mercy for him, he would not feel pain. Do you not see how the one being treated does not feel pain, but rather finds pleasure?

Reflect upon what I have mentioned to you in Divine Knowledge. I have seen it in authentic Unveiling (al-Kashf al-Ṣaḥīḥ) and clear Witnessing (al-Mashhad al-Ṣarīḥ), with the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) beside me. Allah commanded the killing of the Dajjāl (Antichrist) for his claim to divinity, and yet He wept and offered excuses for him regarding the punishment he would receive because of him, saying that he had no control over it. His weeping is like the pain in the soul of the compassionate one who lacks the power to execute his mercy due to a barrier. There is no greater perplexity (ḥīra) in Divine Knowledge than this perplexity. If it were not immense, the Real would not have described Himself with hesitation (al-taraddud), and hesitation is perplexity. Understand this.

The origination of the form of the Eighth *Rak‘ah* of the Witr originated a man from the men of Allah the Exalted, called ‘Abd al-Malik (Servant of the King).

### [The Creature is a King Absolutely, and the Real is the King of the King]

Know that the King (al-Malik) is the one who brought into existence this reality called kingship (mulk). When the servant is named by it, and the Real is characterized by Kingship, He is not characterized by it in the same way as the created being. For the created being is a king (ملك) absolutely, and the Real is the King of the King (ملك الملك), not a King absolutely.

He is not a King to the servant until the servant’s servitude (‘ubūdiyya) to Him the Exalted appears, and until his being a king to his Sovereign (Malīk), who is Allah the Exalted, appears to him. We only said this because of a group whose speculation led them to believe that Allah does not know the particular (al-juz’) specifically, but only knows the whole (al-kull) that encompasses the particular—contrary to the People of the Real, the People of Unveiling and Existence (al-Kashf wa al-Wujūd).

This is why He has the Name *al-Malik* (The King) and *al-Malīk* (The Sovereign). This description appeared due to intensity, because the adherents of this rational speculation do not affirm it. Since the intellects did not agree upon it, a dispute arose. The Real appropriated the title *Malik* (King) for Himself, meaning intensely. And the knowing servant appropriated the Real as his *Malik* (Sovereign), meaning intensely, because of the disputant. He named Himself King of the King (Malik al-Malik) to differentiate between Himself and the created being’s kingship to Allah. The created being is characterized by servitude to Allah in his being a king to Him, while the Real is characterized by the Kingship of the King and is not characterized by servitude to Him. Even though there is an influence from creation upon the Real, as mentioned previously, He is still not characterized by servitude, because that influence is not due to abasement (dhilla), for He the Exalted is the origin of that influence. Nothing returns to Him except what originated from Him. This is contrary to creation, for what originated from the created being returns to him, and what did not originate from him resides in him by an initiation from the Real. Know this.

The origination of the form of the Ninth *Rak‘ah* of the Witr originated a man from the men of Allah called ‘Abd al-Hādī (Servant of the Guide).

Know that Guidance (al-Hidāya) is a Divine effect (أثر إلهي) in His saying: <<مَنْ يُضْلِلِ اللَّهُ فَلَا هَادِيَ لَهُ>> (Whomever Allah leads astray, there is no guide for him). And it is a cosmic effect (أثر كوني) in His saying: <<وَلِكُلِّ قَوْمٍ هَادٍ>> (And for every people there is a guide). The meaning of the latter returns to the former, for the cosmic guide is only a messenger from Allah. He is a conveyor (muballigh), not a guide in the sense of granting success (muwaffiq), but a guide in the sense of clarifying (mubayyin).

He the Exalted said concerning the clarification and explanation that Allah made incumbent upon them: <<لِتُبَيِّنَ لِلنَّاسِ مَا نُزِّلَ إِلَيْهِمْ>> (That you may clarify to the people what was sent down to them). And He said concerning the guidance that is success: <<لَيْسَ عَلَيْكَ هُدَاهُمْ>> (It is not upon you to guide them), meaning, it is not upon you to grant them success in accepting what I sent you with and commanded you to clarify, <<وَلَكِنَّ اللَّهَ يَهْدِي>> (But Allah guides), meaning, grants success to <<مَنْ يَشَاءُ وَهُوَ أَعْلَمُ بِالْمُهْتَدِينَ>> (whomever He wills, and He is most knowing of the guided ones), meaning, those who are receptive to success, for He created them upon a specific disposition (مزاج خاص).

These guides are guides of clarification, not guides of success. The Guide who is Allah possesses both clarification and success. The guide who is a created being possesses only clarification.

We said this and cited this evidence because it is established among those who lack knowledge of realities that if the servant is truthful in what he conveys from Allah in his clarification, it will influence the souls of the listeners. This is not as they claim. For there is none closer to Allah, nor more truthful in conveying from Allah, nor more beloved in acceptance of what he brought from Allah, than the Messengers (may Allah’s prayers and peace be upon them). Yet, acceptance was not universal among the listeners. Rather, the truthful Messenger said in his conveyance: <<وَمَا يَزِيدُهُمْ دُعَائِي إِلَّا فِرَارًا>> (And my call only increases their flight). Since acceptance was not universal despite the certainty of this spiritual aspiration (himma), we knew that the aspiration has no effect whatsoever upon the one being called.

The acceptance that occurred among the listeners did not result from the effect of the aspiration of the caller (the conveyor). Rather, it was accepted because of the disposition (مزاج) that Allah bestowed upon him in his creation, which necessitates his acceptance of this and similar things. This specific disposition is known only to Allah who created them upon it, which is His saying: <<وَهُوَ أَعْلَمُ بِالْمُهْتَدِينَ>> (And He is most knowing of the guided ones).

Therefore, do not say after this: If you attend the gathering of a reminder/caller to Allah and find no effect of his speech in you, that this is due to the lack of truthfulness of the reminder. No, rather the fault is from you, from your own essence, since Allah did not create you at that time upon acceptance. The fair-minded person looks at what this reminder/caller brought. If it is the Truth (Ḥaqq) and he does not accept it, he knows with certainty that the fault is with the listener, not the reminder. If he attends the gathering of another reminder, who brings the exact same remembrance, and it affects him, the listener says, out of his ignorance, "This reminder is truthful, for his speech affected my heart." The fault is with you, and you do not know it.

Know that this influence did not occur because of your acceptance of the Truth, for it was the Truth in both reminders in reality. Rather, the influence occurred in this gathering and not the other due to a relationship (nisba) between you and this reminder, or between you and the time, which influenced you with this remembrance. The influence was not due to the reminder, since the remembrance was present before and had no effect on you. Rather, the suitability (المناسبة) that I clarified to you—whether temporal or the relationship between you and this reminder—was the cause. Perhaps it was influenced by your belief in him, while you had no belief in the other. Thus, nothing influenced you but yourself, or something similar.

This is why we said in the interpretation of Divine Guidance (الهداية الإلهية) that it is both success (التوفيق) and clarification (البيان). Our saying "success" means the agreement of the relationship between the listener and the reminder, not the clarification, for we assumed clarification occurred in both cases from the reminders, yet acceptance occurred in only one of the cases. Know this and realize it, and you will be rightly guided, God willing.

The least benefit in this issue is the safety of the reminder from your accusation of untruthfulness in his reminder and your rejection of the Truth. For the sound intellect is influenced by the Truth, no matter who brings it, even if it comes upon the tongue of a polytheist, an enemy of Allah, a liar against Allah, and one hated by Allah. But what he brought is the Truth, and the rational person accepts it because it is the Truth, not because of the vessel through which it appeared. By this, the seeker of the Truth is distinguished from others.

The origination of the form of the Tenth *Rak‘ah* of the Witr originated a man from the men of Allah called ‘Abd Rabbih (Servant of his Lord).

### [Lordship is Contingent upon Two]

Know that Lordship (الربوبية) is a relative attribute (نعت إضافي). It is not held exclusively by one of the two correlatives (المتضايفين) apart from the other. It is contingent upon two. It is not necessary that they be distinct; they may be distinct, or they may not be distinct. A king (malik) without a kingdom (mulk) cannot exist in reality or estimation. A sovereign (malīk) without a king is likewise impossible. A Lord (Rabb) without an object of Lordship (marbūb) is not valid in existence or estimation. This is the case for all correlatives.

The relationship of the world to what the realities of some Divine Names grant is the relationship of correlatives from both sides. The world seeks those Divine Names, and those Divine Names seek the world, such as the Name Lord (al-Rabb), the Powerful (al-Qādir), the Creator (al-Khāliq), the Benefactor (al-Nāfi‘), the Harmful (al-Ḍārr), the Giver of Life (al-Muḥyī), the Giver of Death (al-Mumīt), the Dominant (al-Qāhir), the Honorer (al-Mu‘izz), and the Humiliator (al-Mudhill), and similar Names.

There are other Divine Names that do not seek the world, but from which the soul of the world finds spiritual relief (yastarwih) without specific detail, unlike the detailed Names we just mentioned. The Names of spiritual relief are like the Rich (al-Ghanī), the Mighty (al-‘Azīz), and the Holy (al-Quddūs), and similar Names.

We have not found any Names for Allah that specifically indicate His Essence (Dhāt) without implying an additional meaning beyond the Essence. For there is no Name except for one of two things: either what indicates an Act (which necessarily requires the world), or what indicates Transcendence (which provides spiritual relief from attributes of cosmic deficiency that the Real is exalted above). Allah has not granted us anything other than this.

There is no proper noun (ism ‘alam) that contains nothing but the quality of being a proper noun for Allah at all, unless it is in His Knowledge or what Allah has reserved in His Unseen (ghayb) and has not revealed to us. The reason for this is that He the Exalted only manifested His Names to us so that we might praise Him with them. It is impossible for there to be a proper noun among them at all, because proper nouns do not convey praise for the named entity. Rather, they are proper nouns for the meanings they indicate, and those meanings are what are used to praise the one whose ruling appeared in us through them—the one named by their meanings. The meanings are what are named by these verbal Names, such as the Knowing (al-‘Ālim) and the Powerful (al-Qādir), and the rest of the Names.

To Allah belong the Most Beautiful Names (الأسماء الحسنى), and these are only the meanings, not these words. For words are not characterized by beauty or ugliness except by dependence on the meanings they indicate. They have no consideration in terms of their essence, for they are nothing more than composed letters and a specific arrangement called convention (iṣṭilāḥ). Understand this.

The origination of the form of the Eleventh *Rak‘ah* of the Witr originated a man from the men of Allah called ‘Abd al-Fard (Servant of the Unique/Odd).

### [That the Unique Quality is only understood by the Just Observer through understanding another matter]

Know that the unique quality (الفردية) is only rationally understood by the just observer through understanding another matter from which this entity, called unique (fard), is distinguished by an attribute that is not present in the entity from which it is distinguished. If it were present in it, it would not be valid for it to be distinguished by it, and the name *fard* would not apply to it.

That from which the unique entity is distinguished must be rationally understood, and it is none other than the even (al-shaf‘). The matter by which the unique entity is distinguished is resemblance to the Oneness (al-Aḥadiyya). The first of the unique numbers is three. Allah described as disbelievers those who said: <<إِنَّ اللَّهَ ثَالِثُ ثَلَاثَةٍ>> (Indeed, Allah is the third of three). If they had said the third of two, they would not have been disbelievers, for He the Exalted is the third of two, the fourth of three, the fifth of four, and so on, reaching whatever number it may. This is His saying: <<وَهُوَ مَعَكُمْ أَيْنَ مَا كُنْتُمْ>> (And He is with you wherever you are).

Whoever is in his oneness (aḥadiyya), He the Exalted is the second of one. Whoever is in his twoness (tathniyya), He is the third of his twoness. Whoever is in his threeness (tathlīth), He the Exalted is the fourth of three, reaching whatever number it may. He is with the created beings wherever they are. The Creator does not separate from them, because the reliance of creation is upon the Name al-Khāliq (The Creator) with a sound reliance, without doubt. Even though this Name requires several meanings, it seeks them—meaning the Name al-Khāliq—by its Essence. Each meaning has an effect in the created being, not in the Creator. The Creator for these meanings is merely the Comprehender (al-Jāmi‘), and their effect is in the created being, not in Him.

The Real is not the fourth in the four, but He is the fifth in the four, because <<لَيْسَ كَمِثْلِهِ شَيْءٌ>> (There is nothing like Him). If He were the very fourth of the four, He would be like them. Every one of the four is the very fourth of the four, without specification. If this were the case, the One of the four would make the Real four by His existence, and the matter is not so. This is the case for every number. Whenever you hypothesize a number, make the Real the One who comes immediately after that number, for He necessarily encompasses it. The fifth of the four encompasses the four, but the four do not encompass Him. He makes them five, but they do not make Him five, for they are four unto themselves. This is the case for every number.

This is so that the number may be preserved for the counted objects, and preservation (al-ḥifẓ) belongs only to Allah. Allah is none other than the One (al-Waḥd). The One must always preserve what is below Him, whether even or odd. He makes the even odd (yūtir al-shaf‘) and makes the odd even (yashfa‘ al-witr). So it is said, "the fourth of three" and "the fifth of four," but it is not said, "the fifth of five" or "the fourth of four" or "the tenth of ten."

The philosophers say concerning uniqueness (al-fardiyya) that it is the odd number (al-witr) from three upwards, in every odd number, such as the fifth, the seventh, and the ninth. Between every two unique numbers is the station of evenness (shaf‘iyya), and between every two even numbers is the station of uniqueness. This is according to the philosophers.

According to us, it is not so. For uniqueness belongs to the One who makes the odd number even, and to the One who makes the even number odd, which the philosophers consider unique. If it were not so, it would not be valid to say concerning the uniqueness of the Real that He is the fourth of three and the sixth of five, and less than that and more. He is unique in every relation. Sometimes He is unique by making the odd number even, and sometimes by making the even number odd. This is His saying: <<مَا يَكُونُ مِنْ نَجْوَى ثَلَاثَةٍ إِلَّا هُوَ رَابِعُهُمْ وَلَا خَمْسَةٍ إِلَّا هُوَ سَادِسُهُمْ>> (There is no secret counsel of three but that He is their fourth, nor of five but that He is their sixth). He only clarified His uniqueness by specific mention as the uniqueness of making the odd number even, which the philosophers do not accept in their terminology of uniqueness. Then He said generally: <<وَلَا أَدْنَى مِنْ ذَلِكَ وَلَا أَكْثَرَ إِلَّا هُوَ مَعَهُمْ>> (Nor less than that nor more, but that He is with them), whether their number is odd or even.

Allah is not one of their evenness nor one of their oddness. Rather, He is the Observer (al-Raqīb) and the Preserver (al-Ḥafīẓ) who <<مِنْ وَرَائِهِمْ مُحِيطٌ>> (encompasses them from behind). Whenever creation moves to the rank that the Real was in, the Real moves to the rank immediately following it. It is impossible for Him to remain in the rank He was in when creation moves to it.

Look at this Divine secret, how subtle and how magnificent it is in Transcendence (al-Tanzīh), in which no participation is valid for creation with the Real. Creation always seeks to catch up with the Real, but is unable to do so because the Real moves away from that rank. This is why number is endless, for if it ended, creation would catch up with the Real, and that will never be. Creation is creation unto itself, and the Real is the Real unto Himself.

An example of this is a group of three in secret counsel gathered in a session. Allah is undoubtedly the fourth of that group. If their fourth is another person who comes and sits with them, the Real moves from the fourth rank, merely by the arrival of that man or person who made them four, to the fifth rank. If they prolong the sitting such that someone comes who makes the group five, the Real moves to the sixth rank. He becomes the sixth of five, meaning the sixth of this group, after He was the fifth of the group that the one person made five. Know this, for I have alerted you to a great knowledge for which you will thank me before Allah. I hope that Allah will benefit me through whoever learns from me what I have mentioned in this discourse concerning the knowledge of Allah, which you will not find in the preceding books of authors in this field.

All of this is a drop from a word of the Glorious Quran. We have nothing from Allah except the understanding of it from Allah, which is the Divine Revelation (al-Waḥy al-Ilāhī) that the Real preserved for us.

This which we have mentioned was the Witr of the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) from the night prayer. As for the completion of the twelve, that is the one called the Guardian (al-Muhaymin), who is outside the origination of the powerful Witr. He is the First One (الواحد الأول), and He is none other than Allah. He is the Originator (al-Munshi’), Glory and Exalted is He in His Grandeur, the One, the Unique (al-Aḥad), who <<لَمْ يَلِدْ وَلَمْ يُولَدْ وَلَمْ يَكُنْ لَهُ كُفُوًا أَحَدٌ>> (has not begotten and has not been begotten, and there is none comparable to Him).

The man by whom the twelve is completed, just as the months are completed by Ramadan—which is only completed by a Name of His Names, Ramadan, the Mighty and Majestic—by Him everything is completed. The completion of the four is by the fifth, when Allah is the fifth of four, for He is the one who preserves their fourness for them. If one of their kind comes who makes them five, the fourness is gone, and Allah is the sixth of the five, preserving their fiveness for them, because He is the Preserver (al-Ḥafīẓ). Look at how astonishing this matter is.

From this, the existing flight (al-firār al-mawjūd) and the transition from state to state are validated, for Allah transitions in the ranks of the numbers for the reason we mentioned.

The name of this man by whom Allah completed the twelve is ‘Abd Allāh (Servant of Allah). He is only named ‘Abd Allāh because Allah manifests to him through the reality of every Name of His Names. This is His saying: <<وَلِلَّهِ الْأَسْمَاءُ الْحُسْنَى فَادْعُوهُ بِهَا>> (And to Allah belong the Most Beautiful Names, so invoke Him by them). If you invoke Him by one of them, He manifests, responding to you in the essence of that Name.

This is like the fasting of the month of Ramadan, for its fasting is obligatory among the twelve months. Every fast in the other eleven months is merely a resemblance to the fast of a day in the month of Ramadan, because it is supererogatory (nāfila). The obligatory fast is only Ramadan by the initial Divine obligation (al-wujūb al-ilāhī al-ibtidā’ī). We said "initial" because of the vow (nadhir) to fast, which Allah made obligatory upon you by your own imposition upon yourself, as a punishment for you, and so that He may reward you with the reward of the obligatory if you fulfill it.

However, the difference between it and the initially obligatory is that the initially obligatory fast must be made up (qaḍā’) if the time of its obligation passes, even if you forgot it or were sick and unable to perform it. But the cosmic obligation (al-wājib al-kawnī) is not made up if its time passes. This is the difference between the Divine Obligation and the Cosmic Obligation.

Whoever knows what we have mentioned concerning these twelve has attained Divine treasures, just as it was said concerning the Fātiḥa that Allah gave it specifically to His Prophet Muhammad (PBUH), excluding other Messengers, from a treasure of the treasures of the Throne (al-‘Arsh) that was not found in any revealed Book or scroll except specifically in the Quran. By this, it was named Quran, because it combined what was revealed in the Books and scrolls and what was not revealed. In it is everything in all the revealed Books, and in it is what was not revealed in any Book or scroll.

In this Station are the sciences of Loosing and Binding (al-Ḥall wa al-‘Aqd), the science of the lawful and the forbidden (al-Ḥalāl wa al-Ḥarām), the science of what gathers the disbeliever and the believer and creates harmony between them, the science of attaching animals to humans in the ruling of some legal judgments, the science related to the perfection of certain individuals, the science of sanctification (al-Taqdīs) and its causes and types, the science of Divine blessings and favors (al-Ālā’ wa al-Minan), the science of covenants and pledges, the science of the origination of the forms of bodily worship, the science of cosmic magnification (al-Ta‘ẓīm al-Kawnī), the science of Divine debts (al-Mudāyanāt al-Ilāhiyya), the science of Faith (al-Īmān), the science of the Substitutes (al-Abdāl), the science of the Divine Call (al-Nidā’ al-Ilāhī), the science of definition, the science of establishing proofs for claims, the science of the People of the Intervals (Aṣḥāb al-Fatarāt) and their ruling with Allah, the science of what pertains to the king and the common people, the science of deputation in the call, the science of rejection and acceptance, the science of delegation and submission (al-Tafwīḍ wa al-Taslīm) in souls, the science of veiling and returning things to their origins, the science of establishing the One in the place of the whole in any station, the science of agreement and disagreement, the science of the accountability of the compelled (al-Majbūr), the science of audition (al-Samā‘), the science of light and spiritual meaning and guidance, the science of parables, the science of following and followers, the science of testimonies, the science of the Return (al-Ma‘ād) and its ruling, the science of fear and caution, the science of homogeneity between things, the science of love and its nobility and the types of lovers, the science of casting off restraint in it, the science of specialization, the science of the abrogation of inner realities in general and specific terms, the science of likening the Real to creation (tashbīh al-Ḥaqq bi al-Khalq) and what is permissible of that and what is not, and its relation to hearing, in which the intellect has no entry by its own speculation, the science of gift and acquisition (al-Wahb wa al-Kasb), the science of what is incumbent upon the Messenger, the science of the ruling in Unity (al-Tawḥīd) for one who names Allah with a name other than His, the science of the degrees of misguidance and leading astray and the differences therein, the science of commanding the good and forbidding the evil, the science of the influence of creation upon the Real, the science of what caused the People of the Books wretchedness, the science of lifting hardship and the ranks of the pious, the science of choice, the science of the nobility of places over one another and what it returns to, the science of the control of the lower over the lower, the science of relating things to their origins, and the science of hinting at goodness.

<<وَاللَّهُ يَقُولُ الْحَقَّ وَهُوَ يَهْدِي السَّبِيلَ>> (And Allah speaks the Truth, and He guides to the way).
